entry.title: Re: Why no Delete options for Comments, Answers, Posts, Q...
entry.content:
Hi @Sijin_Chandran - this is mainly due to EU's Digital Services Act as @Dominik_Tylczynski also mentions. 

To stay DSA compliant, we need to always create a DSA case when content is deleted, and inform the author of why the content was deleted. Delete permissions are complex (even on the old platform you were only allowed to delete content as long as it had no children, ie. no comments or answers). To ensure DSA compliance, the delete persmissions were therefore restricted to the SAP Community team moderators last year when DSA went into effect. 

Having said that, we are continously reviewing options and evaluating our moderation practices within all the different regulations that are being introduced globally currently. (other than DSA in the EU, we now also have similar regulations either already in place, or emerging, in the UK, Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, Vietnam, China, India, South Korea, Japan, Brazil and California)

entry.title: The delivery date in the schedule line of the sales order item is appearing incorrectly.
entry.content: In Public cloud We have created a new plant, 5002. However, when I create a sales order from this plant, the delivery date in the itemâ€™s schedule line is incorrect. For example, if I create a sales order on 13.09.2025, the delivery date is automatically set to 17.09.2025. If I use any other plant, the delivery date is correct. Please suggest a solution.

entry.title: How to collaborate on an entity of a draft enabled RAP Business Object ?
entry.content:
Introduction

With the latest release 2508 of SAP BTP ABAP Environment a new feature called Collaborative Draft has been delivered.  This feature allows that several users can work on the same draft instance of an entity of a RAP Business Object. 

So similar like collaborating on a file in Microsoft Teams it is now possible that several users can perform changes on an entity of a RAP Business Object at the same time.

The cool thing is that every draft enabled RAP BO can be enhanced so that it also supports Collaborative Draft without the need to change the existing ABAP code of your behavior implementation class(es).

It is only required to change a few lines of code in the behavior definition, the behavior projection and you have to create a draft query view  which projects all fields of the draft table of the "authorization master" entity which in most cases this is the root entity of your business object.

In case your active business object view entity is protected by a DCL (which is strongly recommended for every productive RAP business object ğŸ˜‰)  the draft query view must also be protected by a data control language (DCL) that inherits from that existing DCL.

This because otherwise users would be able to see data in the draft they would not be allowed to see in the active data.

Please note:  
As described in the section Outlook the implementation will become even easier in the future once table entities will be supported as a draft persistency instead of tables.   

Prerequisites

  1. You need a draft enabled RAP Business object (which you can easily generate using the new "from scratch generator").
  2.  Your user and any other user that is supposed to use / test your RAP BO must have the new business catalog  SAP_CORE_BC_RAP_DRAFT_PC assigned which is part of the business role template
    SAP_BR_EMPLOYEE. 
    You have hence first to ask your administrator to either generate an additional role based on the role template SAP_BR_EMPLOYEE or let the administrator assign the business catalogue to an existing role which is assigned to developers on your SAP BTP ABAP Environment system, so that you and your colleagues can start developing and testing this cool new feature.

Result

In the following you see me (Andre Fischer) and the user ANZEIGER working on the same instance of a draft entity. As soon as a user leaves the focus of a field the changes will be updated automatically in the UI of the other user.

You can test the collaborative draft setup even in systems where you have just one user, like in our trial systems.

In the first screen shot I am editing the field "Notes" (highlighted in red) and I can see that I am editing the field "OrderID" in the second tab (highlighted in green).

In the second screen shot we see vice versa that I am there editing the field "OrderID" (highlighted in red) and that I am editing the field notes in the other session in the first tab.

Implementation Steps

A step by step guide which describe how to enhance an existing draft enabled RAP Business Object has been provided for your convenience to the SAP Online Help.

An example of a RAP Business Object has also been delievered as part of the well known Flight Reference Sample with the latest version in Github which now contains an additional sub package /DMO/FLIGHT_COLLDRAFT.

Implementation Walkthrough

I will add a few screen shots on how I have enabled my small RAP BO using the above mentioned documentation. As shown in the following screen shot only the behavior definition and the behavior projection have to be changed and two additional objects, the draft query view for the draft table of the root entity and the DCL for the draft query view have to be created.

1. Changes in the behavior Definition

As described in the documentation the we have specify in the behavior definition that collaborative draft is used instead of exclusive draft and for the root entity we have to add the use of the draft query view for the draft table and we have to add the action Share.

2. Changes in the behavior projection

In the behavior projection we simply have to add use statements so that the collaborative draft is used for our RAP business object and we have to enable the action Share.

3. Create new object - Draft Query View

4. Create DCL for the Draft Query View

Outlook

In future releases, when table entities will be supported to store the draft data instead of tables it will not be necessary anymore to create a draft query view for the draft table. This is because in this case the table entity itself can be directly secured by a DCL.

The setup shown in this blog post will be presented in upcoming events such as the sitBE Event in Mechelen, the DevToberFest and naturally TechEd and TechConnect events later this year.

 

DevToberFest Sample

And you can find the code of the sample application which shows a Shopping Cart with a header and a child entity for items that I will use in this blog post soon in Github as well. 

For the implementation I used the "from scratch generator" and as a template for the root entity I used the following structure

@EndUserText.label : 'Shopping Cart Header Data'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
define structure zdmo_cart_## {

  currency                : abap.cuky;
  notes                   : abap.char(100);
  order_id                : abap.numc(8);
  requested_delivery_date : fins_caldate;
  @Semantics.amount.currencyCode : 'zdmo_cart_##.currency'
  total_price             : abap.curr(11,2);

}

while for the child entity this structure was used

@EndUserText.label : 'Shopping Cart Item Data'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
define structure zdmo_item_## {

  item_id         : abap.numc(8);
  ordered_item    : matnr40;
  quantity        : abap.numc(4);
  currency        : abap.cuky;
  @Semantics.amount.currencyCode : 'zdmo_item_##.currency'
  item_price      : abap.curr(11,2);
  @Semantics.amount.currencyCode : 'zdmo_item_##.currency'
  item_unit_price : abap.curr(11,2);

}

entry.title: Re: The delivery date in the schedule line of the sales o...
entry.content:
The system calculates the confirmed delivery date in the schedule line by running delivery scheduling and transportation scheduling. The calculation uses:

  • Shipping point lead times (picking/packing time, loading time)
  • Route transit time (if a route is determined)
  • Transportation lead time
  • Factory calendar for the plant and shipping point

If plant 5002 is new, itâ€™s very likely that:

  • The shipping point assigned to plant 5002 has default lead times (e.g., 2 days picking + 2 days loading), or
  • The route determination for plant 5002 â†’ customer is assigning a route with a transit time of 4 days, or
  • The factory calendar for plant 5002 has nonâ€‘working days between 13.09.2025 and 17.09.2025, which pushes the first possible goods issue date forward.

Thatâ€™s why you see a 4â€‘day gap for plant 5002, but not for other plants.

entry.title: Re: IDoc 0000000000075134 and determined transport type E...
entry.content: The error "IDoc and determined transport type EXTPAY do not match" (IHC_IDOC639) occurs because the system cannot correctly determine that your payment is an external payment. The most common root cause is missing SWIFT/BIC code in the master data of the external vendor's bank. The system uses this code to distinguish between internal (TRANSF) and external (EXTPAY) payments.

entry.title: TM PPF Output Management for Business Partners (partner dependent action)
entry.content:
We use S/4HANA 2023 FPS02 and I have a TM related questions. We are in the shipper scenario.

We defined the freight order output (the PDF which we send to our carrier for the transport service) as action. It works.

We recognized that we can set an action as partner-dependent. This makes sense, because we want to send the freight order only to our carriers.

We set our action for the freight order as "Partner dependent". The action is only relevant for U3 Carrier.

Now it does not work any more.

The output configuration guide Output Management Configuration Guide says that you need to redefine  GET_COMM_PARNR_BY_ABAP to get the partners. OK, wired enough that you need to code such a basic requirement, but we did it.

 

The action is now determined âœ… in the FO, but the execution fails, because the system does not determine the default communication method (E-Mail, Print), language,... everything what was "standard" in NAST. We assume that's the issue.

The help documentation Output Management for Business Partners | SAP Help Portal explains that there is an Output Management area in the Business Partner (BP). We configured all data sets, screen groups and screens, included everything in the BP role....but, we cannot find the "Output Management" fields in the BP transaction. We assume, there you can define required information for the action. Are we wrong? Is this Output Management tab part of S/4 or only a relict of old TM?

Does anyone have a few more information for us how we can achieve to get the carrier communcation details automatically into the FO? Before we start with redefinition of many methods in the PPF "toolbox" we were wondering if there is any out of the box logic to send an email to the carrier.

Thank you

entry.title: Re: TM PPF Output Management for Business Partners (partn...
entry.content: @Ronald_Knienieder The issue is not a bug but a fundamental architectural difference. In the old NAST world, output parameters were stored statically in the Business Partner (BP) master data. In the new PPF world, these parameters must be determined dynamically at runtime by redefining specific methods in the PPF agent class. The "Output Management" tab in the BP is a relic of the NAST era and is not used by TM's PPF output management in S/4HANA.The solution is to enhance the standard PPF agent class for the Freight Order business object to provide the missing communication data (method, address, language) by reading it from the correct parts of the BP master data.

entry.title: Re: TM PPF Output Management for Business Partners (partn...
entry.content:
The Output Management tab in the Business Partner was not part of NAST. For NAST, I defined in condition records how the partner shall receive the output (channel, language). I don't see this as "oldfashioned" ğŸ˜‰

Thanks of course for your reply. I hope there is still some other feedback that we can easily determine the output channel w/o ABAP. I mean, it's a standard solution and using classes/methods/Badis....not really sure if this is the way to go for a really basic requirement.

entry.title: Re: What is the best approach in SAP ECC to transfer asse...
entry.content: @Gourav_Deshmukh The optimal and standard SAP-recommended approach is to use the automated intercompany asset transfer transaction (ABT1N). You do not need to align or deactivate areas 70 and 71 in the receiving company code. Instead, you will leverage SAP's Cross-System Depreciation Areas configuration to explicitly define which areas transfer their values. By leaving areas 70 and 71 unassigned in this configuration, they will be seamlessly excluded from the transfer process.Attempting to manually retire and acquire the asset is error-prone, misses automatic reconciliation features, and is not best practice for this scenario

entry.title: Re: TM PPF Output Management for Business Partners (partn...
entry.content: You are right, the old way was not "old-fashioned" it was a different, highly effective architecture.The classic NAST (Message Control) framework did not rely on the BP's Output Management tab for default values. Its power and flexibility came from the condition technique

entry.title: Re: Unable to Create WT for Returns Delivery, item shows...
entry.content:
Dear @Lakshmi_Priya96,

the stock type in your warehouse has nothing to do with the stock type of your delivery.

The stock type of the delivery in your case most likely comes from the returns purchase order item. Could you please check the item in the 'Purchase Order - Advanced' app in the tab 'Delivery'? There you see the stock type for the item from where it should be picked.

You can also check the LE Delivery item on the administration tab.

This stock type is taken over to the warehouse delivery.

In order to correct that you need to reverse your existing delivery. Afterwards you can correct the stock type of the purchase order item and create a new delivery.

 

best regards, Marius

entry.title: Re: SAP Enable Now - Bulk Function (bubble, font style) t...
entry.content:
Tools - Replace Bubble Styles. This will mass replace bubble styles in sims. 

As for the book pages, you can do the following: 

DISCLAIMER: for experienced users only. If you break your local workspace, I won't feel guilty ğŸ˜.

    1. Open the book page's slide.js or slide.xml file and locate the technical ID of the legacy bubble style. e.g. "big_title_bar_light_theme"
    2. Find the ID of the bubble style you want to use as a replacement. I won't explain how, because if you can't find it, you shouldn't proceed to the next steps.
    3. Start editing all the book pages.
    4. Using Notepad++, run the command Find in Files
    5. Replace all the occurrences of the legacy bubble style in the files slide.xml, slide.js with the new bubble style in the <path to your workspace>\slide folder

  1. Return to Producer, and select Workspace - Refresh Workspace ad All Objects
  2. Save your changes to the server.
  3. Enjoy.

entry.title: Re: Automatic Sales order exctraction
entry.content:
Hello @SKAE 

Thank you for your question.

Based on your screenshots and the error message, it seems the scope is fine.

To resolve the issue, first, you need to activate communication scenario SAP_COM_1129 in your communication arrangement app. This should point to the document information extraction service instance. Make sure the user creating the communication arrangement has the correct communication management role.

Then you need to make sure the document extractions service instance is available in your BTP subaccount. Make sure you create a service key for the instance.

Once you have activated and connected SAP_COM_1129, re-run the prerequisite check in the intelligent scenario management. The connection error should no longer be visible and you will be able to activate the deployment.

Consult the following references for more details.

KBA 3452093

Communication Scenarios

Document Processing and Information Extraction

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Table TOBJ list of authorization EHP8
entry.content:
Hello @manthana99c17,

have you done the SU25?

If not yet, it would display auth related changes caused by upgrade to EHP8, on auth object and values level and also the impact on default auth values (tables USOBT*) if SU24 maintained  by values for your company's SAP roles.

Once all steps done in DEV, including SU24, careful check of all roles have been touched by upgrade to EHP8, and also including roles adjustments, I suggest to import changes roles to QAS and ask business users to test and ensure the roles content.

Regarding changes like new auth object/s, etc., check USOBX* tables, there are stored differences between DEV before upgrade and DEV @ EHP8.

Proceeding SU25 and then maintaining of SU24 would cover any new auth objects because when is Merge used in PFCG, extended content will be added into role/s.

SU25 and SU24 are quite helpful to keep roles consistent and working.

In case of any other question, don't hesitate to ask ğŸ™‚

BR, Olga

entry.title: Customer on account payments Scope item 1S0 - SAP Digital Payments
entry.content:
Dear Team,

Customer has a requirement where the sales rep would intend to process customer on-account card payments and match it against open invoices on the same payment processing screen. 

We are using SAP Digital payments add-on solution and was exploring scope item 1S0-Customer payments (specifically apps "Make Ad-hoc Payment" and "Pay my Bills") to meet above functionality.

However, the above scope item 1S0 has been deprecated in 2508 and will be reinstated back in 2602. SAP alternatively has planned to make APIs available on 18th Sep using which customers can build their own payment portal.

Customer is reluctant to build any custom portal as they are subscribed to a standard DPA solution which defeats the purpose if we go for an interim custom payment portal solution for few months.

The other alternate solution that we have communicated to the customer is to use PSP dashboard offline to make such payments but again the matching of payments to invoices will not be automated here and it create 2 diverse process (order payments and on-accounts payments) for sales rep to follow which is not acceptable for the customer.

Can you please suggest if any of you are in a similar situation and if any other alternatives are being explored at your end to mitigate & address above requirement ?

Kunal

entry.title: Re: Why Does BAPI_SALESORDER_CREATEFROMDAT2 Show Wrong Co...
entry.content:
In pricing, KBETR is not stored as the â€œhumanâ€‘readableâ€ amount; it is stored in internal units based on the conditionâ€™s pricing unit (KPEIN) and condition unit (KMEIN). For example, if your condition type ZGTC is defined in customizing with Calculation type = per 100 units (or per %), Pricing unit = 10 or 100, then the internal value in KBETR is scaled accordingly. The display in VA02 multiplies the stored value by the pricing unit to show the â€œper unitâ€ rate. So if you pass 94 with a pricing unit of 10, the display will show 940.00. This is a classic unit/scale mismatch when calling the BAPI.  The BAPI doesnâ€™t â€œfixâ€ it, it just stores what you give it, and the UI applies the scale.

The SAP note referred here explains the Condition value is multiplied by factor 10â€) addresses a known scaling issue in older releases where the BAPI multiplied the passed condition value incorrectly because of missing or wrong pricing unit handling. If your system release is one of those covered by the note, and the symptom matches the noteâ€™s description (value multiplied by 10 unexpectedly), then applying it can help.

However, in most modern releases, the behaviour youâ€™re seeing is by design.  You need to pass KBETR in the internal format: KBETR = <desired display value> / <pricing unit> and set KPEIN (pricing unit) and KMEIN (condition unit) correctly in the BAPI tables ORDER_CONDITIONS_IN and ORDER_CONDITIONS_INX.

So with the above findings, what you can do is check condition type ZGTC in V/06:

  • What is the calculation type?
  • What is the default pricing unit?

Pass matching KPEIN/KMEIN in the BAPI along with KBETR.  If you want 94.00 to display in VA02, and the pricing unit is 10, you must pass KBETR = 9.4 with KPEIN = 10. Only if you confirm youâ€™re on a release where Note 886532 applies and the scaling is wrong despite correct KPEIN/KMEIN, should you apply the note.

entry.title: Re: Problem with activation of Business function (BS sets...
entry.content:
Please note when you activate a business function in SFW5, the system switches the switch framework status. Tries to activate the associated BC Sets into your customizing tables. If the BC Set content does not match the current table structure or existing entries, the activation terminates with â€œPostprocessing necessary when upgrade/update completedâ€.

In your case, the â€œError when comparing BC Set â€¦ with customizing tablesâ€ means the BC Set content delivered for EAâ€‘HR in 2023 FPS03 is not matching the current table definitions or entries in your fresh system. This can happen if the BC Set contains entries for tables that have been changed or are not yet generated in your client. There is a mismatch between the EAâ€‘HR delivery package and the Support Package stack youâ€™re on. The BC Sets require postâ€‘upgrade activation steps (IMG activities) before they can be applied.

Please proceed with the below steps

Check SFW_BROWSER for EAâ€‘HR dependencies. Some EAâ€‘HR switches require other switches (e.g. HRâ€‘related industry solutions) to be active first.

Run transaction SFW5 in â€œSimulationâ€ mode to see the list of BC Sets and objects it will touch; note any that are redâ€‘flagged.

In SCPR20, try activating EAâ€‘HRâ€‘AKH, EAâ€‘HRâ€‘IMG, EAâ€‘HRâ€‘MENU one by one. If they error, the long text will tell you which table/field is mismatched.

Sometimes SAP delivers correction BC Sets or adjusts the activation sequence in a note. Search for notes with component BC-SRV-SFW and PA-* for your release.

If the BC Sets fail because tables are missing, generate the missing tables by running the relevant HR IMG activities (e.g. Personnel Administration basic settings) before reâ€‘running SFW5.

If this is a demo or sandbox and you just need EAâ€‘HR active, you can force the switch active in SFW_BROWSER and then manually run the HR IMG to configure; but in a productive system you should resolve the BC Set mismatches properly.

With all the above steps performed and still if you feel, you are on a fullyâ€‘patched FPS03 system and all prerequisites are met, then raise an incident to SAP under component BCâ€‘SRVâ€‘SFW

entry.title: Re: What is the best approach in SAP ECC to transfer asse...
entry.content: Configure Cross-System Depreciation Areas to map only the common areas (01, 10, 20, 30) and deliberately exclude the sender-only areas (70, 71). Then, execute the transfer using transaction ABT1N.

entry.title: Re: How to check which Auth Checks a program in SAP does
entry.content:
Hello @radinator!

To extend role by Fiori app could be a bit challenging, but described time waste dancings in a loop have never been needed.

There are more ways howto.

As oldschool SAP Authorizations, I prefer to have prepared special test user with unlimited rights in QAS, start authtrace in background and then ask business to log into SAP using this special user and with the Fiori app do what required. Once done, I check authtrace, identify related  values and fill them into SU24. On S/4 is possible create variants for every t-code, so I do, then merge role with new values and generate profiles. If the"test task" was done right way, after that all needed rights should be in role.

Using these steps for each new rights requested in last years. Seems complicated but proven as helpful, the bonus given is the consistency kept quite easier ğŸ™‚

BR, Olga

entry.title: Part 2: Agentic AI â€“ Governance, risks and dilemmas
entry.content:
Agentic AI is jet another evolution of Traditional AI, right? It brings more than Generative AI (GenAI), but is also carries out some more risks as wellâ€¦ Itâ€™s becoming â€œsmartâ€, itâ€™s making â€œdecisionsâ€ â€“ and IBM told us in 1979 we shouldnâ€™t let computers make â€œdecisionsâ€ because computers cannot be â€œaccountableâ€[1]!

Iâ€™ve tried to explain the AI evolution path in my previous article (Agentic AI â€“ AI which finally makes sense?). Now, letâ€™s talk about governance, risks and ethical dilemmas.

We should be aware of it, and we should try to address it â€“ in timeâ€¦

Letâ€™s start with dilemmasâ€¦

Agentic AI can make autonomous decisions and based on this it can execute some complex tasks â€“ also autonomously. This can be useful, yes â€“ for sure this is much more than just GenAI assistants, where we had to make the decision and execute task on our own. Now we can have real robotic personal assistants, or self-driving cars, or robotic support agents. Tomorrow (and this tomorrow can come very fast) we will have fully autonomous HR agents and procurement officers, as well as fully autonomous industrial and humanoid robots, and letâ€™s say this loudly â€“ war robots as well (oh, I am sure bunch of people are already working on it, as we speak).

Figure 1. Are we concerned?

Dilemma is clear â€“ where does this lead us at the end? Are we, out of our curiosity (or need to simplify our lives?) producing something which can replace us, or worse?

I do not have an answer on this â€“ future is unwritten chapter â€“ we are writing it now.

Agentic AI is reality, and now we should find the best way to use it! But at the same time,  we must create our future in a smart and sustainable way â€“ and I hope we will.

Now, risksâ€¦

As per risks with Agentic AI, like with any AI or GenAI, there are some â€œstandardâ€ risks, for sure. But here I see that primary risk, is the risk of misuse by design â€“ and this I link with the above dilemmasâ€¦ I am not referring only to wrong design (i.e. being bias), I am referring on more serious â€œintentionalâ€ use for the â€œwrongâ€ cause. What kind of agents and robots do we want to build? How much autonomy do we really want to give to AI? Although there are many articles, there are effectively no binding principles and guidelines. We are still too much intrigued with Agentic AI (or AI in general) â€“ so no boundaries are set.

But it should be! As long as we do not set reasonable (and sustainable) boundaries, we are at (major?) risk.

Figure 2. Key Risks leading to shortcomings

For the â€œstandardâ€ risks, we have all those any GenAI might have â€“ starting with security vulnerabilities like prompt injection and data poisoning, to model hallucinations. With Agentic AI both can lead not just to â€œillâ€ recommendations, but to â€œbadâ€ decisions and â€œwrongâ€ actions taken.

Additional risk, also starting with GenAI â€“ the more cognitive tasks we pass to AI, the less cognitive tasks we will execute â€“ this may not be good, in the long run. Similar with Agentic AI â€“ the more decisions and actions are done by AI, the more dependent we become â€“ again, this is not good for us, in the long run.

Are we aware of these risks? Well, we should beâ€¦

Can we improve â€œthingsâ€ with good Governance?

The key aspect of any governance is to, among others, minimize any shortcomings of the new tools, methods, projects etc. How can we do this for Agentic AI?

  • How do we ensure that Agentic AI System has been built in the transparent and explainable way â€“ so we can easily understand its purpose and ability?
  • How do we ensure Agentic AI is fair and responsible â€“ that we do see it as non-bias in making decision?
  • How do we build-in accountability within Agentic AI System (even these are â€œcomputersâ€) â€“ in a way humans can accept it (also avoiding misuse by design)?
  • How do we ensure Agentic AI System is safe to operate of â€“ prompt injection and data poisoning has been effectively prevented.

Many questionsâ€¦ But what are the key governing principles we must follow?

First and the most important â€“ there are no strict or imposed principles and guidelines (at least not yet) what is that Agentic AI System (agent or robot) can and cannot do by design. So, if we talk about â€œformalâ€ misuse of the technology â€“ sorry there are none or close to none (at least formally) limitations. But â€œinformallyâ€ yes â€“ there are those â€œdilemmasâ€ for potential misuse of the AI (by design).

While it looked like we were very far away from the â€œrealâ€ AI (it was just a hype, right?) we did not care too much about putting any â€œlegislationâ€. However, now things do not look so distant... The closer we come to real technology break-through toward autonomous robotics â€“ thighs are becoming more and more controversial.

So how to build AI, and especially Agentic AI (or some further evolutions) in a responsible manner?

Figure 3. Responsible AI is Human-centric

Letâ€™s call this Responsible AI magic circle of â€œinteractionâ€:

  • Agentic AI â€œimposesâ€ certain Risks
  • Risks do â€œimpactâ€ us, Human
  • Human must â€œbuildâ€ Governance rules and practices
  • Governance rules and practices are here to â€œcontrolâ€ Agentic AI

The fact currently there are no â€œlegallyâ€ binding rules and principles, does not prevent us to set company or industry standards on our own â€“ letâ€™s call it AI best practice.

If we talk about rules, letâ€™s start thinking â€“ what is that we want to keep for ourselves? What is that we donâ€™t want AI to do? How far are we from some futuristic scenarios and the need to build basic rules of robotics[2]? Maybe we should be ready to â€œmove overâ€ this mountain and embrace the fact â€œfuture is happening right nowâ€!

For principles, things are a bit more straight-forward, and previous AI experiences can really help us:

  1. Risk management: identifying, assessing, and mitigating the unique risks posed by both GenAI and autonomous agents. We should try to address all risks; from compliance risks and what and why do we build (to be transparent and explainable, to be fair and responsible, and ensure maximum possible accountability), to security risks (to be safe to operate).
  2. Continuous monitoring and auditing: agents/robots need to be monitored continuously to detect any deviation from intended behavior, any ethical issues, or security breaches. Also, audit trails and logging of agent decisions are vital for accountability, where (ideally) no agents/robots should access, alter and remove any audit trails and logs.
  3. Organizational structure: creating a cross-functional AI governance boards and bodies to create policies but also monitor adaptation of these policies in all Ai initiatives, with special focus on agents/robots.

All this, and more if needed, can be easily translated into any organization dealing with Agentic AI. Each organization will make adaptations on its own, of course â€“ but key is to be aware of risks and shortcomings, as well as all the potential benefits new Agentic AI technology is bringing. If we are aware, and we try addressing it with proper governance â€“ itâ€™s a good startâ€¦

So, can we start all this and be open-minded?

Acknowledgment

*) Intro photo BoliviaInteligente on Unsplash

**) This article uses SAP Business Technology Platform Solution Diagrams & Icons as per SAP Terms of Use  governing the use of these SAP Materials (please note, newer version of the Solution Diagrams & Icons, as well as Terms of Use, might be in place after the publication of this article).

More guidelines on Solution Diagrams & Icons can be found in this article by Bertram Ganz.

References

[1] IBM: AI decision-making: Where do businesses draw the line? | IBM

[2] Isac Asimov: Three Laws of Robotics - Wikipedia

entry.title: Skills in SAP SuccessFactors: Field Guide for a Clean Build (TIH, JPB, CPM, OMP)
entry.content:
Skills in SuccessFactors only clicks when you separate people from jobs: Growth Portfolio (TIH) for people, Job Profile Builder for roles. This guide shows exactly what to enable, how to govern signals and write-back, and how to prove value in 90 days.

Applies to: SAP SuccessFactors Platform: Talent Intelligence Hub (TIH) / Growth Portfolio, Job Profile Builder (JPB), Performance & Goals (incl. CPM), Opportunity Marketplace, People Intelligence.

Why read this: If youâ€™re setting up or rescuing a skills program in SuccessFactors, this is the no-nonsense blueprint: what owns what, what to enable, what to measure, and what to avoid.

 

One idea to anchor everything

People â‰  Jobs. 

In SuccessFactors, people skills live in the Growth Portfolio (TIH Job Role details live in Job Profile Builder. Donâ€™t try to force one to replace the other. Map roles and required attributes in JPB; curate and evidence peopleâ€™s skills in TIH. Most downstream confusion disappears when you keep those two sources of truth separate.

Architecture at a glance

  • Talent Intelligence Hub (Growth Portfolio): the person-centric skills profile (attributes, proficiency, evidence, history).
  • Job Profile Builder: job-centric content (families, roles, competencies/skills). Consumed by Recruiting, Performance, etc.
  • Signals & Inference: Continuous Performance Management (CPM) can feed TIH to recommend skills; you promote to confirmed with governance.
  • Opportunity Marketplace (OMP): skills drive opportunity matching; completions can surface as growth evidence.
  • People Intelligence: the analytics destination for skills coverage, gaps, mobility, think â€œpost-WFA.â€

Enablement: the minimal viable path

1) Turn on Growth Portfolio (TIH)
Admin Center â†’ Company Settings â†’ Manage Talent Intelligence Hub â†’ Portfolio Settings â†’ Enable

2) Seed the Attributes Library
Admin Center â†’ Growth Portfolio â†’ Add from Attributes Library â†’ Set proficiency scales
Recommendation: Start with 3 pilot families; cap role profiles at 15â€“25 skills to keep matching sane.

3) Keep JPB as the job backbone
Use families/roles and attach the right attributes.

Recommendation: Donâ€™t flood; use Core vs. Nice-to-have.

4) Wire CPM â†’ TIH inference (optional but powerful)

  • Enable â€œAllow CPM data to support skills inferencing in TIHâ€ via AI Services Administration.
  • In Scheduled Jobs, verify three CPM â†’ TIH jobs (Achievements / Activities / Feedback) show COMPLETED SUCCESSFULLY; otherwise your â€œAIâ€ sees nothing.

5) Opportunity Marketplace hygiene
Ensure opportunities are tagged to skills; confirm that opportunities and completions surface in Growth experiences (incl. non-intelligent recs in skill detail).

Governance that actually reduces noise

  • Naming rules: one canonical label per skill; merge duplicates monthly.
  • Role caps: keep roles lean (â‰¤40 skills).
  • Evidence rules: define what counts (learning completion, gig completion, manager validation).
  • Skill owners: assign by family; review quarterly.
  • Change control: Promote INFERRED â†’ CONFIRMED via admin workflow, not ad hoc.
    These basics improve match quality more than any â€œmagicâ€ toggle. (Principles derived from SAP docs + partner implementation notes.)

Privacy and compliance notes (donâ€™t skip)

If you infer skills in the EU, treat them as personal data. Use DPCS 2.0 where applicable; ensure lawful basis, notices, and opt-outs are documented. Works-council agreements donâ€™t replace GDPR obligations, get both right.

Fast checks:

  • DPCS 2.0 enabled in Provisioning and statements created per country.
  • Audit acceptance in Admin Center â†’ Data Privacy Statement â†’ View History / View Log.

Reporting: stop thinking like old WFA

Plan your shift to People Intelligence to mix skills + mobility + business metrics. Thatâ€™s the arena where execs see impact (time-to-fill, internal moves, project margin), not just skill counts.

Also: use the out-of-the-box TIH Stories.
Report Center â†’ Story â†’ Content Store has ready-made Story templates you can import and tweak. They run on People Analytics (Stories), so you can report directly on TIH/Growth Portfolio objects: Attributes, Attribute Types, Tags, Growth Portfolio, Behaviors, Proficiency Levels/Sets, without building a model from scratch. Start with these templates:

  • SF_TIH_Talent_Intelligence_Hub_HR_Admin_Dashboard
  • SF_TIH_Talent_Intelligence_Hub_Manager_Dashboard

 

then add pages for coverage, gap-to-role, mobility, and evidence quality. If you see duplicate rows in Growth Portfolio stories, thatâ€™s the history (effective-dated) view, switch to â€œlatest record onlyâ€ in your query

Cost control: budget the AI, not just the project

TIH (Growth Portfolio) is part of platform at no additional cost. But, the premium AI features consume SAP AI Units â€“ all AI services listed below. Track and estimate usage early or your pilots stall later.

  • Where to track: Admin Center and SAP for Me consumption dashboards.
  • How it works (estimator & catalog): SAPâ€™s AI Unit Estimator / Business AI catalog.

Open skills: donâ€™t start from zero

If your library is thin, lean on partners that sync with TIH to solve cold-start: TechWolf, Degreed, and others announced by SAP. Use them to normalize and ingest signals rather than hand-curating everything.

A 90-day rollout that works

Days 1â€“15: Foundation

  • Enable TIH; clean JPB families/roles; seed a small, governed library.
  • Define evidence rules; assign skill owners.

Days 16â€“45: Signals & flow

  • Switch on CPM â†’ TIH inference via AI Services; verify scheduled jobs.
  • Tag opportunities; validate that Growth experiences reflect completions/recs.

Days 46â€“90: Prove value

  • Publish People Intelligence dashboards (coverage, gap-to-role, internal mobility).
  • Run one mobility or gig pilot; track time-to-fill and redeploy rate.

 

FAQ

Q: Can Performance form ratings update Growth Portfolio automatically?
A: Performance consumes attributes for rating, but write-back to Growth Portfolio isnâ€™t automatic; design the evidence path or integrate via APIs/imports if you need it.

Q: Do opportunities â€œwrite backâ€ to peopleâ€™s skills?
A: You can surface opportunity recommendations in Growth experiences and use completions as evidence, but verify enablement and tagging; donâ€™t assume full automation.

Q: Is People Intelligence just a rebrand of WFA?
A: Itâ€™s a next-gen analytics approach announced in 2024/2025 communications (built on SAPâ€™s data cloud direction). Plan migration; donâ€™t keep building WFA-style reports.

Q: How do I control AI cost?
A: Monitor AI Units; use the estimator and catalog; review consumption regularly in Admin / SAP for Me.

References:

  • Talent Intelligence Hub / Growth Portfolio â€” overview & enable steps. (SAP Help Portal)
  • Job Profile Builder â€” concept & content types. (SAP Help Portal)
  • CPM â†’ TIH skill inference â€” concept + job checks. (SAP Help Portal)
  • Opportunity Marketplace interactions â€” recommendations in Growth experiences. (SAP Help Portal)
  • AI Units â€” tracking & estimation. (SAP Help Portal)
  • Privacy â€” DPCS 2.0 and admin auditing. (SAP Support Portal)
  • Open skills partners â€” TechWolf, Degreed & Any 3rd party. (SAP News Center)

entry.title: Field Mapping Mechanism and Troubleshooting Guide for Error "No Sales Scheduling Agreement Found"
entry.content:
This blog describes the field mapping mechanism and troubleshooting guide (from SAP backend) for the error "No Sales Scheduling Agreement Found" in the delivery schedule EDI, with the communication scenario SAP_COM_0444 (Sales Scheduling Agreements With Buyers Integration).

"Image/data in this blog is from SAP internal systems, sample data, or demo systems. Any resemblance to real data is purely coincidental." 

Step 1: Find the related EDI Message ID via T-code /AIF/ERR:

Step 2: Get the payload via T-code SRT_MONI:

Step 3: Get the values of related fields from the payload.

Below is the mapping of fields among the EDI payload, the sales scheduling agreement, and the "Assign Sold-to Parties" app:

EDI Payload

Sales Scheduling Agreement"Assign Sold-to Parties" app

PurchasingSchedulingAgreementID

Customer Reference 

BuyerProductID

Customer Material in the item of Sales Scheduling Agreement 

<Party PartyType="SoldTo">

<BuyerPartyID> 10100003 </BuyerPartyID>

</Party>

Sold-to PartySold-to Party

<Party PartyType="Supplier">

<BuyerPartyID> 10100001 </BuyerPartyID> 

</Party>

           

Supplier

<Party PartyType="Plant">   

<BuyerPartyID> 1010 </BuyerPartyID>

</Party>

Ship-to Party: Partner DefinitionPartner Description

<Party PartyType="DepartResp">

<BuyerPartyID> 0001 </BuyerPartyID>

</Party>   

 Unloading Point

Note: "Supplier" is optional in payload and the "Assign Sold-to Parties" app. However, if it is in the payload, it should also exist in the "Assign Sold-to Parties" app.

Step 4: Open the "Display Sales Scheduling Agreements" app and input the related search criteria (according to the EDI Payload) to find the corresponding sales scheduling agreement:

 Step 5: If the values among the EDI payload, the sales scheduling agreement (SA), and the "Assign Sold-to Parties" app don't map, no sales scheduling agreement can be found.

Below is a positive example where the sales scheduling agreement can be found:

(1) Values in the EDI payload:

(2) Values in the "Assign Sold-to Parties" app:

entry.title: Reusable APIs in SAP Integration Suite : Design Once, Use Everywhere
entry.content:
Introduction

Reusable API  artifacts in SAP Integration Suite â€“ Edge Integration Cell are modular, internal-only APIs that encapsulate common cross-cutting concerns such as authentication, transformation, validation, or logging.

Instead of duplicating the same policies across multiple APIs, Reusable API s act as centrally managed building blocks that can be invoked by other API artifacts through the a special API Direct adapter.

 Key characteristics:

Internal only: They are not exposed as standalone endpoints.

Policy encapsulation: Common logic like authentication or schema validation is defined once and reused.

Independent lifecycle: They can evolve separately from consuming APIs, supporting cleaner governance and versioning.

Performance-aware: Optimized for low-latency chaining between calling APIs and Reusable API s, with correlation IDs ensuring full traceability.

Consistency & compliance: Authentication policy is enforced uniformly across the execution chain.

Use Cases it Addresses

Reusable API artifacts address several real-world challenges faced by API developers and central security/governance teams:

ğŸ”‘Centralized Security Enforcement

Instead of configuring authentication and authorization separately in every API, organizations can define a Reusable API  artifact with standard security policies (e.g., OAuth/JWT verification, API key validation, IP allowlist). Any new API simply invokes this artifact, ensuring compliance with enterprise-wide standards and reducing the risk of inconsistent security coverage.

âš™ï¸Policy Reuse & Reduced Duplication

Enterprises often repeat the same transformations (e.g., XML-to-JSON), validations (e.g., schema checks), or response formatting across multiple APIs. By centralizing these policies into Reusable API  artifacts, teams avoid duplication, simplify maintenance, and accelerate delivery of new APIs.

ğŸ“ŠAuditability & Governance

With traceability built in via correlation IDs, Reusable API  artifacts give central teams visibility into how APIs interact across the execution chain. This is particularly useful in regulated industries where demonstrating uniform enforcement of policies (like logging or data masking) is mandatory.

ğŸš€Accelerated API Development

Developers can focus on business-specific logic in their APIs while leveraging pre-built Reusable API  artifacts for cross-cutting concerns. This speeds up delivery, ensures consistency, and lowers onboarding time for new API projects.

 Creating and consuming a Reusable API Artifact

   Prerequisites
  • Enable API Management and Cloud Integration capabilities  and 
  • Provision Edge Integration Cell runtime.

After you have setup Edge Integration Cell and enabled both the capabilities mentioned above, you will have option to create API artifact. 

         In a typical organization, two key personas benefit the most from reusable API artifacts in SAP Integration Suite:

  1. Central Security Administrator â€“ responsible for defining and enforcing security standards across all exposed APIs. They ensure consistent authentication, authorization, and compliance policies without duplicating effort.
  2. API Developer â€“ responsible for designing APIs in Integration Suite, modelling business logic, and creating proxies for backend services. With reusable APIs, they can focus on business functionality while relying on centrally managed security and governance.

Lets create a Reusable API as security administrator persona :

 A Security Administrator logs in to the Integration Suite tenant and navigates to Design â†’ Integrations and APIs, then selects an existing content package to model a Reusable API.

              

Select the Edge Integration Cell runtime profile and proceed to choose the API creation method. Among the four available options, you will notice a new entry: Reusable API.

 

 

Provide the required API details to create a Reusable API .

 

Important to note: A Reusable API artifact does not require a target URL or a virtual host since it is designed for internal invocation only via a calling API artifact using the API Direct adapter. Therefore, it does not have an externally invokable endpoint.

Once all the details are provided, click on Create to create a Reusable API .

 

The sender adapter in a Reusable API is automatically set to API Direct. This is important because it allows the calling API artifact to invoke the Reusable API internallyâ€”without an HTTP endpoint and without external exposure. Now, letâ€™s add a few security policies like Authentication and Authorization to it.

 

 

 

In addition to security policies, you can add mediation policies to extend functionality. For example:

  • Use a Content Modifier to enrich or adjust the message payload.
  • Configure an External Callout to log data to external services such as Loggly.

 

With these steps, weâ€™ve modelled a Reusable API that handles authentication and authorization, while also logging transaction details to an external system.

Consuming the Reusable API

Letâ€™s model a caller API that proxies an external backend while consuming the Reusable API created in the previous steps.

 

 

Provide the mandatory details for the caller API.

For a standard API, an Authentication policy is always applied as the first policy by default. However, when consuming a Reusable API that already includes an authentication policy, you should remove the default authentication policy from your calling API. This ensures thereâ€™s no duplication or conflict.

As a boundary condition: The first step in your calling API must be either Authentication policy or a Reusable API with Authentication policy as its first step. This keeps the flow clean, avoids redundant auth checks, and maintains proper execution order.

Now, letâ€™s add a step to invoke the Reusable API created earlier. As the first step, add the reusable API artifact as a global reference in your caller API, as shown below. 

The Reference dialog will display only the deployed Reusable APIs within a package. If you need to reference multiple reusable APIs, you can add them from different content packages simultaneously.

To consume the reusable API, add a Request-Reply step along with a Receiver System to invoke the reusable API. From the list of adapters, select API Direct only. Since the reusable API already includes an Authentication policy, go ahead and delete the authentication policy from your calling API to avoid duplication.

 

Letâ€™s click on API Direct to configure the adapterâ€™s connection details, which enables us to reference the reusable API added earlier as a global reference in this API.

 

Now, letâ€™s examine the properties associated with the API Direct adapter in detail.

 

 a) Resource :This allows you to associate any added reusable API as a reference to this API.  

 b) Address :A read-only field that displays the basepath of the reusable API added in the Resource section. 

 c) Send Body  :Check this box to send the original request body to the reusable API. This is typically used with   POST, PUT, or PATCH methods, where the request payload must be preserved and forwarded to the reusable     flow. 

 d) Retain Original Body for Next Steps : Select this option to keep the original request body available for use in subsequent steps of your caller API.

 e) Headers

  • Request Header: Enter a pipe-separated list of headers (e.g., Authorization|X-Correlation-ID) to send to the reusable API.
    Use * to send all headers by default.
  • Response Header: Enter a pipe-separated list of headers from the reusable APIâ€™s response that should be merged into the caller APIâ€™s original request headers.
    Use * to receive and merge all response headers by default.

Now we have modelled and consumed a Reusable API into the caller API. Please note that if the Reusable API is not deployed, then you will not be allowed to deploy the caller API referring that Reusable API . Now letâ€™s deploy the caller API.

As both caller and Reusable APIs are deployed, Lets check the status and also invoke the caller.

Monitor and Message logs

Once APIs are deployed lets navigate to Monitor section to introspect the both Caller and the Reusable APIs under Manage Integration Content.

 

One important point to note about reusable APIs is that, since they donâ€™t have an external endpoint, the Endpoints section does not display any entry as shown above.

 Let change the log level to Trace for both the artifacts.

Now let me invoke the caller API endpoint via a REST client.

 

Letâ€™s now check the correlation ID for this transaction in both the caller and reusable API logs â€” they should ideally be the same, ensuring end-to-end traceability.

As you can see, the API was invoked successfully.

If you recall from earlier steps, we modelled the reusable API to provide Authentication & Authorization protection and included a mediation policy to log the correlation ID to the Loggly server.

As you can see, the same correlation ID is also being logged into the Loggly server.
Additionally, you can examine the trace details of the executed steps, which will show that the first step was executed via API Direct, exactly as we modelled in our use case.

 

Similarly, the same Reusable API is referred  to another API artifact by the API developer to leverage the centrally defined security and common tasks by administrator.

If a new traffic management policy like Surge protection policy is to be added to all the APIs then API administrator only needs to it to the Reusable API and it will be automatically applied to all the APIs referring the Reusable API.

Points to remember:

  1. At least one authentication policy is mandatory in complete chain including the caller API and Reusable API.
  2. Only Authentication policy or a request reply step to Reusable API can be added as first step in a valid caller API.
  3. A caller API can refer more than one Reusable API, but one Reusable API cannot refer another Reusable API.
  4. Only deployed reusable APIs can be added to the caller API.

Summary

Reusable API artifacts in SAP Integration Suite bring clarity and efficiency to API management. By separating centralized enforcement from API development activities, organizations can achieve both governance and agility. The administrator gains confidence that policies are consistently applied, while the API developer can focus on delivering business value without reinventing the wheel for every project.

In short, reusable APIs strike the right balance between control and productivity, making them a cornerstone for scalable, enterprise-grade API strategies.

entry.title: Re: Streams in RAP : Uploading PDF , Excel and Other Files in RAP Application
entry.content:
Hi,
@RadhikaKuthiala 
@sandhyad 
@Mahiba 

When uploading a file via a child association(Line Items on Root Object Page) in an OData V4 service,
the error Entity set '' not found (/IWBEP/CM_V4_MED015) appears.

This only happens when accessing the attachment field through the parent entity (ROOT).
Uploading directly via the child service works fine,
and the file is then also visible through the parent as expected.

Solution:

I extended the object page of the ROOT entity,
and overrode the client-side upload function to redirect the file upload directly to the child entity's service.
This avoids the "Entity set not found" error and ensures successful uploads.

Code Snippet (Controller Extension):

sap.ui.define(['sap/ui/core/mvc/ControllerExtension',
    'sap/m/MessageToast'
], function (ControllerExtension, MessageToast) {
    'use strict';

    return ControllerExtension.extend('studentapp.ext.controller.StudentObjectPage', {
        override: {
            /**
             * Called when a controller is instantiated and its View controls (if available) are already created.
             * Can be used to modify the View before it is displayed, to bind event handlers and do other one-time initialization.
             * @memberOf studentapp.ext.controller.StudentObjectPage
             */
            onInit: function () {
                this.getInterface().fixBugEntitySetNotFound();
            },

        },

		/*
			changes upload url 
		    From : "/sap/opu/odata4/sap/zhr_sb_student_v4/srvd/sap/zhr_sd_student/0001/ZHR_C_STUDENT_APP(parentKeys...)/_Attachments(childKeys...)/Attachment"
			To:    "/sap/opu/odata4/sap/zhr_sb_student_v4/srvd/sap/zhr_sd_student/0001/ZHR_C_STUDENT_ATTACHMENTS(childKeys...)/Attachment"
		*/
        fixBugEntitySetNotFound: function () {

            if (!sap.ui.unified.FileUploader.prototype._bUploadOverwritten) {

                sap.ui.unified.FileUploader.prototype._bUploadOverwritten = true;
                var fOrignalUpload = sap.ui.unified.FileUploader.prototype.upload;
				
                sap.ui.unified.FileUploader.prototype.upload = function (bPreProcessFiles) {

                    /* Extend - Begin */
                    var sParentService = "ZHR_C_STUDENT_APP", //root service
                        sChildService = "ZHR_C_STUDENT_ATTACHMENTS", //child service
                        sChildAssociation = "_StudentAttachments",
                        sUrl = this.getUploadUrl(),
                        sNewUrl = "";

                    if (sUrl.includes(sParentService) &&
                        sUrl.includes(sChildAssociation)) {

                        sNewUrl = sUrl.split(sParentService)[0] + sChildService + sUrl.split(sParentService)[1].split(sChildAssociation)[1]
                        this.setUploadUrl(sNewUrl)
                    }
                    /* Extend - End */

                    fOrignalUpload.apply(this, arguments);

                };
            }
        }
    });
});


Best Regards,
Ben.
